tickets.description:
ISSUE:
We currently use NCAR's mailman server as our mailing
list home.  We then echo all our mail lists to SF b/c
the NCAR mailing lists cannot be searched.  
But:
\- the SF archive has been scrubbing attachments
\- our mail forwarding from NCAR to SF gets
auto-unsubscribed and we don't know how to stop that
from happening

REQUIREMENTS/DESIRES:
\- ability to search mail archives
\- ability to archive attachments
\- archive interface needs to be web-based and support
any \(Mac/Linux/Unix Netscape/IE/other\) browser
\- nice to keep ucar.edu extensions for lists
\- nice to create a continuous archive, e.g. fill in
holes in past support request archive, for example

OPTIONS:
1\) An external third party software like hypermail or
mhonarc. Two sections at NCAR are currently using
hypermail.
Questions:  Support for all browsers?

2\)Get the WEG to create an organization-wide mail
search and archival solution.
Status:  I first approached the ITC about this and they
referred me to the WAG/WEG for the solution. I have a
meeting the the WEG group head to explore this.  
\- Sylvia
Questions:  Time required to create a custom solution?

3\)Keep the NCAR+SF solution
Status:  wrt the issue of our SF archiving breaking
periodically, I have submitted a support request
through SF on this issue to diagnose it. - Sylvia
Actions:
\- Look at whether other SF projects are able to archive
\- Search SF support archives for similar questions

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

There are two issues here, the NCAR mailman instance and the
SF instance. 

SF instance:

we are getting any archival of attachments at all. I
contacted SF and they pointed me to the content filtering
portion of the mailman administration portal.

a\) The default they had in there was to only archive text.
I changed the filtering rules to include various mime 
types and tested them. It did not change anything. 

b\) I then turned off all filtering which should     
theoretically allow all attachments through. Still not
none were archived. 

c\) I updated the SF work request. It is an open request.
Is SF any better than we are about resonding? Who knows
it has been sitting there a while.

d\) I have scanned all other SF and Mailman support           
requests out on the web. Mailman should work given what
SF recommended. I am not sure why it is not.
posts.author: murphysj
posts.subject: #1 Mailing list archival and search

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

NCAR instance:

Problem 1: we can't search w/o installing a third party
software package like hypermail \(discussed in another update\)

Problem 2: certain attachments, principally MS Office
related files come out at .obj files when sent from both
Sylvia's and Silverio's MACs. We don't know yet if this is
MAC wide but we think so. 

I spent a day going through every mailman support request
ever submitted to python.org that relates to this issue.
Here are some of my technical findings:

a\) email clients determine the file extension of attachments
based upon their mime type. They then create a content-type
and put this in the header of the email.

b\) mailman determines the extension of an archived
attachment by first guessing and then comparing this guess
with what the content-type is. If they do not match, the
scrubber.py in mailman goes with its guess which may be
wrong. This is to protect against viruses and such. 

c\) there was a bug in mailman that to the extensions of 
MS documents and made them gibberish. A patch was released
but other people were getting this .obj distinctions.

d\) thunderbird looks at mimeTypes.rdf for downloads and
upload extensions. Sometimes the user's version of this file
can get goofed up. In my case it has not been modified from
the system default and there for that should not be an issue.

e\) Some tests:
mac/thunderbird   mac/macmail  linux   windows

.xls           fail          fail       pass     pass

.rtf                     all pass

.pdf                     all pass

.doc          pass           fall       pass     pass



d\) Greg woods reported that he scanned other archives for
similiar MS -> .obj issues and found many other archives
that have similiar problems. I am going to find the owners 
of these list and find out what platforms they are on. 

e\) someone out on the ether recommended the following fix:
change the line:
filebase, ignore = os.path.splitext\(filename\)
to:
filebase, ext = os.path.splitext\(filename\)

greg woods is hesitant to do this but is willing to test it
under some controled circumstances.

The following documents what we know about option 1,
external third party software:

Hypermail is a free executable that you run on mail folders
to turn them into HTML files with mail organized by subject,
author, date, and alphabetically. It works in all browsers
b/c it is simple HTML. We would have to administer. Mary has
an executable sitting in her bin directory on Meeker. 

Advantages: free and simple

Disadvantages: not automatic. Mary saves the mail, runs
hypermail on it, and then copies it to the Web server.


Another package is  MHonarc: http://www.mhonarc.org/
It works similiarly in that you run a script and convert the
mail archives to HTML which are then searchable. 

Hmmm, I wonder what format native mailman archives are in?

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

Had meeting with Markus and Leonard about an organization
wide mail search. They asked me to submit an extraview
ticket so that the powers that be can argue over who should
do it. This is the text of my ticket:

ESMI has numerous mailing lists that are archived. There is
no search mechanism for these archives. Because of this, we
duplicate
the archives on SourceForge where they can be searched. SF
does not allow the archiving of attachments, however, so
this forces
us to duplicate effort and maintain two archives. This is a
productivity sink. 

Two other groups, NCL, and Marla's section use hypermail to
create their own searchable archives. The program is
implemented separately and is manually controlled. This
seems wasteful. We need an organization-wide ability to
search mail archives.  This
should be automated. 

Some archives e.g. CSAC need to remain private however so
some mechanism to distinguish the two is required. 

We do not care what search engine is employed.

This is a key issue for our group which includes the folks
here at NCAR, our other members at several locations around
the US, and
our funders, NASA and NOAA, so the priority is relatively
high for us. We would rather not implement our own version
of hypermail or 
monArch to do this and perpetuate simultaneous solutions.

latest comments from greg:

Unfortunately, I have hit a bit of a snag; this isn't going
to be nearly as easy as I thought it was. The problem is
that Mailman stores all attachments in the archives too,
including for lists that don't have archiving turned on. So
just blindly copying the public archive directory will not
work, as it will make all the attachments searchable,
even those that are attached to messages that are supposed
to be available only to list members. Somehow I will need to
determine which lists have public archiving turned on and
copy only those directories. That implies some database
lookups \(and some knowledge of Mailman internals that I
currently lack so that I will know what to look up\),
which immediately makes the project 10 times bigger than  a
simple rsync of a directory tree.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

the following is a copy of the email traffic related to the
google search option for mail archives:

Try typing something like "emsf\_support WACCM" into Google.
You get
pointers to messages in the esmf\_support Mailman archives.

The reason I ask this is because WEG wants to use Google as
the search
engine for the archives, and I would like to know what we
will gain by
doing this beyond what you can already do with Google. I
will grant that
searching on lists with very short names is difficult
because you get a
lot of hits that have nothing to do with our lists, but I
can search the
esmf\_support archives pretty effectively right now by typing
"esmf\_support" followed by other search terms into Google.
What exactly
is needed that can't already be done this way, and will WEG
implementing
Google searching locally provide it?

This came up because of yet another ethics issue. Namely, a
number of
mailman lists do have public archives, but they're not
advertised lists.
That means, if you know the list is there, you can already
get to the
archives even if you're not a subscriber \(example: cdp,
cosmicdiscussion\), but those lists are not currently
findable through
Google \(may need some help from some of you web experts to
confirm
this\). This means archives for these lists cannot be made
publicly
available either. This will even further complicate creating
a list of
lists to put into the search engine. This is turning into a
giant rat
hole and I at least want to make sure it is really necessary
before
crawling down it.

\--Greg

Sylvia,

It appears Greg is right. Google is already indexing all the
ESMF public Mailman archives. When I tested an archive, I
went into the WORD list which is limited to members. When I
saw the auth come up, I just figured that was happening for
all Mailman lists, but I now realize yours are wide open and
are being indexed by Google.

So, it appears, your needs are already being met without any
action on our part. You can even construct a Google search
form that limits your search results to
ste:mailman.ucar.edu. For more info see our Google search
documentation page.

http://www.cisl.ucar.edu/weg/services/search.shtml

Let me know if we can close the ticket.

Markus



I tested this and we were only getting a small subset of
messages from google. Markus then replied:

Sylvia,

Try doing the "esmf\_support sujay" search from the search
form at the top of the www.ucar.edu page. I see 183 results.

If you do the same search at google.com, you get 211 results
but it only shows 4 results due to Google's algorithm that
omits very similar entries.

I am still pretty confident that Google is indexing all your
lists fully.

Markus


And \(surprise surprise\), if I grep -i for sujay in all of
the html files
in the esmf\_support archive and print out the file names
that match,
there are exactly 211 of them.

\--Greg


I went to the ucar web site and type esmf\_support sujay into
the box and got a slew of reponses.

So, C would you test this out and see if that meets your needs?

I submitted three test emails to esmf\_support. None of the attachments made it through. My conversation about this with greg woods was obtuse. Here is his comment:

There are bugs in Mailman. I do not know how to fix these problems
without spending a lot of time on it. This is really the same as it has
been since the problems were first identified.

I have a ticket in to investigate possible fixes for Mailman that may
already be out there, but as I mentioned before, this is not the highest
priority right now.

\--Greg


What I don't understand is why this was working before and is not now. These "bugs" in mailman were not something we discussed beyond what is already in this ticket, namely, the changing of mac generated .xls files to .obj files in the archives.

It might be time to bring this issue up to a higher authority and indicate that it is effecting us and therefore its resolution should be at the top of greg's queue.

On 27 December Greg woods reported he had upgraded mailman. We did not know how this upgrade would effect our tests.  The group did a series of tests. It appeared that the change in mailman did effect our tests but Greg did not believe me.  So, I created the exhaustive summary below which covers all our tests.  the bottom line is that things changed but there were too many variables to determine the exact cause.

below is my report along with the conclusion. I am also going send this report to greg.

Mail Archiving tests:

definitions:

Passed: The attachment exists and has the correct extension.

Potential variables:

a\) mailman user configuration
b\) mailman system configuration
c\) mailman version
d\) sender operating system
e\) sender mail client

hard to eliminate all these variables to test appropriately.


Initial  tests sent to esmf\_core

27 Sep
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-September/001284.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: .xls
status: partial failure. extension changed to .obj

27 Sep
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-September/001285.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: .rtf
status: passed

27 Sep
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-September/001285.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: .pdf
status: passed


Greg, Sylvia,  Cecelia and Silverio continue tests to test@ucar.edu to see if our mailing list configuration is the issue

28 Sep
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-September/000035.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: xcel
status: partial fail. attachment extension is .obj

28 Sep
from Greg
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-September/000036.html
system: ??
file: same xcel file as above
status: passed
comment: this message was held for moderator approval


28 Sep
from Greg
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-September/000037.html
system: ??
file: same xcel file as above
status: passed
comment: same as above w/o moderator approval

28 Sep
from Greg
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-September/000038.html
system: thunderbird on linux
file: same xcel file as above
status: passed
comment: change operating system and mail client

28 Sep
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-September/000039.html
system: thunderbird on mac
file: .doc
status: passed
comment: since excel files fail when sent by sylvia to esmf\_core & test but not by greg, sent an word document. 


9 Oct
from Cecelia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-October/000040.html
system: PC using mozilla mail
file: .xls
status: passed

9 Oct
from Cecelia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-October/000041.html
system: linux
file: .xls
status: passed

9 Oct
from Silverio
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-October/000041.html
system: mac using mac mail
file: .xls
status: partial failure, extension changed to .obj


9 Oct
from Silverio
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/test/2006-October/000042.html
system: mac using mac mail
file: .pdf & .doc
status: partial failure, .doc extension changed to .obj, pdf passed.


Summary:

Pre changes to mailman version. No changes to user mailman configuration here:

excel files failed by sylvia and silverio \(on macs\) but not by greg and cecelia \(linux and PC\).  

word documents passed by sylvia \(mac\) and cecelia \(pc\)  but not silverio \(mac\). 

pdf passed by silverio and sylvia \(mac\)

rtf  passed by sylvia \(mac\)

Failures at this point were just changes in the extension to .obj.  
Problem seemed to be primarily associated only with excel files sent from macs, regardless of mail client. 


\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*
At this point, I checked to see the status of content filtering for all our mailing lists. All lists had content filtering turned 
off, so I sent a test .rtf file to esmf\_support.  The archival should have passed since the setting for both lists were the same.  It did not pass. why?

23 Oct
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/esmf\_support/2006-October/004585.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: .rtf
status :  failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"

greg could not fathom why the test to this mailing list would fail when tests to esmf\_core passed.  So I sent several more
tests of other document types to esmf\_support. 

8 Nov
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/esmf\_support/2006-November/004689.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: .doc
status:  failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"


8 Nov
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/esmf\_support/2006-November/004690.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: .pdf
status: status: failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"


8 Nov
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/pipermail/esmf\_support/2006-November/004691.html
system: Mac powerbook G4 using thunderbird
file: image
status: status: failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"


Summary:

esmf\_core archives esmf\_support does not even though they were exactly configured.

\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*
Before I got around to further testing, Greg reported that the mailman software had been upgraded. He did not know if that would effect what  we have seen. The group initiated a series of tests to see what might have changed. 



27 Dec
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002295.html
system: mac with macmail
file: unknown \(2 files probably pdf and xls\)
type: content filtering set to off
status: failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"


27 Dec
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002296.html
system: mac with macmail
file: unknown \(2 files probably pdf and xls\)
type: content filtering turned on but only default mime types listed
status: failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"


27 Dec
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002297.html
system: mac with macmail
file: unknown \(2 files probably pdf and xls\)
type: content filtering turned and many "pass" mime types listed
status: failed "Skipped content of type multipart/mixed"


27 Dec
from Sylvia
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002298.html
system: mac with macmail
file: unknown \(just one, probably pdf\)
type: content filtering turned and many "pass" mime types listed
status: failed , no indication file existed at all. 


Summary:

before the upgrade these files would have been archived. After the mailman change, these same types of tests failed.
Unfortunately, sylvia's mail client changed during this interval which adds another variable to the mix which makes it impossible to indicate that the new mailman upgrade is causing this issue. 
\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*\*

Below are additional tests to see how other systems behaved


27 Dec
from:  Samson
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002302.html
system: windows XP
file:  PDF
status: passed


27 Dec
from: Samson
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002303.html
system: Windows XP
file:  .xls
status: failed.  No indication attachment existed at all. 

27 Dec
from: Samson
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002304.html
system: Windows XP
file:  .doc
status: passed


27 Dec
from: Samson
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002305.html
system: Windows XP
file:  .ppt
status: failed. no indication attachment existed at all


27 Dec
from: Rosalinda
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002305.html
system: Mac OS x Version 10.3.9 \(webmail\)
file:  .ppt
status: failed.  attachments looks like:
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/attachments/20061227/44405025/attachment-0001.tar


27 Dec
from: Don
http://mailman.ucar.edu/mailman/private/esmf\_core/2006-December/002308.html
system: From a G4 powerbook running 10.4.8 and using mac mail.
file: pdf
status: passed


Summary:
Not sure what we can glean from these tests. there is no consistent pattern with the failures. 




OVERALL Summary:

It seems that every possible variable that can effect mail archiving does effect archiving in seemingly random ways.
We have had sufficient success that if we really need to archive an attachment and a sender initial fails we can send it to someone else who may be able to archive it successfully.  At this point I am not sure it is worth spending a whole lot of time on the issue.

tickets.description:
ISSUE:

Currently users send esmf\_support an email, Silverio
opens a support request, we have to manually add the
support number to our replies, Silverio has to manually
copy these to a separate mail archive.  We have to
manually connect bugs and support requests.

REQUIREMENTS/DESIRES:
\- must be easy for the user to send a request for help
\(\#1 priority\!\)
\- team should get mail on requests and replies
\- nice to be able to automatically link bugs and
support requests
\- developer should be able to search on what is
assigned to them
\- developer should be able to archive replies easily -
preferably automatically
\- developer/manager should be able to search by customer
\- nice to search by code or institution
\- easy for a manager to view a history by
request/code/customer
\- easy for other users to see what is being done and
how a solution for one person might affect others
\- easy for funders to see that we are responsive to our
community.
\- should be able to generate reports on \#requests over
time, open/closed, per developer

OPTIONS:

i\)Use the SF interface directly \(no more support list\).
Think this will be too confusing for users. - Cecelia

ii\) Bugzilla:  CCSM is currently using this.
Status:  Mariana gave Syliva a tour.
Questions:  Features?  Is it supported for all
browsers?  Is CCSM only using this internally?  It
looks like they are still using a BBS as their external
interface to support.

iii\) Extraview: SCD using this system. We might be able
to use it but it would involve an extra registration
which would not be good for users.

iv\) Continue using the esmf\_support list together with
the SF support tracker.
Status:  If search/archiving can be fixed that helps. 
However, there's still a lot of manual hassle to this
solution, especially if we take into account customer
and adoption tracking too.

ACTION:  Can everyone currently see the mail folders?
ACTION:  Create prototype CRM dbase
ACTION:  Finish and publish to website support procedures

v\) Custom database
This would enable us to link support, customers,
institutions, and status of individual support requests
with the adoption status of codes.  But - maintenance,
time and cost required, security.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

For the record:

This is the full text of Igmar's response to my question on
whether we could use extraview for our support process.
Since we already decided not to go this route, I was not
going to document this, but markus just emailed me asking if
we might proceed:

Sylvia,
ExtraView would consider someone at NASA as a Customer.  All
the NASA
people would need to do is self register using the New User
Registration
link on the login page.
https://schcustomersupport.ucar.edu
There are five required fields \(red\) the new user would need
to fill in
to gain limited access to ExtraView \(add and view an issue,
but not edit
or update an issue\).  Their issue would then route to SCD
Customer
Support \(CPG\), who would then transfer the issue to ESMF. 
The ESMF
members would have to be setup as Resolvers in the system,
so they can
update the issue and the customer via email and eventually
close it
out.  If you decided to use ExtraView for ESMF issues, then
you would
need to educate CPG as to the type of issues you deal with
for your
Customer community, and we would need to probably setup internal
categories which would fit the type of issues you resolve.  The
information you provide would need to be added to CPG's
knowledge and
routing document.  In the application CPG is the first point
of contact
for the Customer.  Also you would want to see if the current
application
would allow you to resolve your issues correctly.  If SCD
Help Desk were
to be used by ESMF, this would need to by approved by our
Change Control
group.  This is made up of Linda La Brie, Dick Valent,
Markus Stobbs and
myself.
Thanks,
Ingmar



I told markus we were not interested at this time b/c
extraview as too much of a NCAR brand and it also involved
yet another login for folks.

tickets.description:
ISSUE:
We don't currently have a tracker that enables us
to have an application code or customer view of the
groups we interact with.  This is a problem because
\- we are not taking advantage of outreach opportunities
\- we don't follow up with people who download, or track
the progress of small ESMF-based projects
\- we aren't making sure that we are resolving all the
issues that a particular customer or code has that
stand in the way of ESMF adoption.  This is important
because we usually need to take care of a suite of
things in order for a particular customer to move their
ESMF code into production
\- we don't manage the interfaces to customers all that
well - the same customer may end up dealing with a
bunch of different people, without any coordinated
oversight
\- we aren't collecting good metrics about how many
codes are ESMF compatible, what the adoption status of
codes is, how satisfied \(or unsatisfied\) customers are,
and what obstacles stand in the way of user adoption.

REQUIREMENTS/DESIRES
\- For each ESMF code or wanna-be code, record contact
people, agency, institution, adoption status, ideally
associated support requests, type of component, and
notes from any direct contacts.
\- View by customer or code.
\- Interface should be browser based, with some fields
such as customer number with limited access.  ~All
browsers have to be supported\!

OPTIONS:
i\) SF code tracker
Status:  This is easy to set up and I went ahead and
did a prototype.  Main issues:  there is only a limited
amount of information it can store, it can only append
info, and it can't track back to support requests
automatically. - Cecelia

ii\)Bugzilla or a similar package?
Questions:  Is there a package out there that does some
customer tracking along with support request tracking?
\- Cecelia

iii\)Custom database
Questions:  Time required to implement, security
issues, resources?

iv\)FreeCRM
Can store more information than SF.  Downside, codes
assigned don't appear on the mySF page with other
assignments.
ACTION: implement prototype dbase

posts.text: - **summary**: Customer and adoption tracking --> Client Relationship Managment (CRM)
posts.author: murphysj

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

freeCRM is actually really cool and easy to use. I have
created companies for CCSM, NCEP, and MIT. I can then create
contact for each of those with lots of info like phone
numbers, birthdays etc. I can automatically generate a call
list \(e.g. tasker\) from reviewing contacts. There is a
search capability and a place to put notes. Something like
this could work for us.

Advantages:

\- very organized and searchable
\- additional features like call and task lists
\- can export to text file
\- can create unique fields and modify existing fields. 
e.g. the field for status was modified to reflect ESMF
status types. We created new fields for program    
information

Disadvantages:

\- yet another software package
\- longevity of company?
\- no tech support unless you pay
\- yet another log in
\- not as transparent to our clients and sponsors as SF, but
we can give folks access as required which might mitigate this.

Custom Solution:

It would be relatively painless to create a MySQL database
hosted on the UCAR server and accessed via python interfaces. 

Advantages:
\- We own and customize it
\- Can create program, contact, code etc tables and cross
reference
\- Backed up locally
\- More easily changed 



Disadvantages:

\- Long development time when we need something now
\- Code could be developer centric. e.g. if the web interface
is in python and I leave, whomever takes my place might be
a PHP person and not understand the code.
\- Note terribly transparent as we would like it to be
\- Opens up the whole world of maintaining web security which
to be done properly is time consuming.

posts.text:
Logged In: YES 
user\_id=1596389

wow, discovered some very interesting things last night and
this am. In addition to technical details, I am going to put
this in perspective a little:

history lesson:

We are seeing a huge growth in distributed projects like
ours because of the technological revolution that began with
the creation of the 
a\) internet \(just the hardware side here\)
b\) the PC which allowed for individuals to create documents
c\) Windows which made doing more on pc's easier
d\) WWW which created that world wide interface that we
know and love
e\) the dot.com boom which laid down fiber optic cables
around the world
f\) AND FINALLY work flow software

what is facinating here is that work flow is becoming the
next great leap forward. This ties into the potential NCAR
work flow project for modeling but also how projects and
companies do business. 

To a great extent, the work flow revolution is corresponding
with another revolution which is hosted software. Instead of
purchasing a software lisence, there is a trended to hosted
software where the IT is handled remotely and customers pay
a per month fee to access a solution that includes data
storage. This is what is empowering the outsourcing of
technical call centers, tax preparation, and distributed
software development. Google's experimentation with
spreadsheets is an example of this trend. I wonder if they
plan to charge for this at some point in the future?

ESMF is a distributed project and we need host software
tools for client relations, bug tracking and support request
tracking. As an open source project though we need to
minimize our expenses. Many of the main vendors out there
are expensive. 

\* Seibel has teamed up with IBM for a hosted
CRM solution which is far more sophisticated than we need.
They charge $70/user/month.  

\* Quicken has a whole suite of 
software including a customizable data base. I was very
quickly able to generate two relational tables, one for
codes and the other for programs and customize them in
several ways. They charge $249/month for 10 users +
$15/month for each additional user. What is our budget?

While the opensource and freeware industry has been able to
provide lots of software that ngo's, labs, and educational
institutions have used to keep their costs down, this trend
toward hosted software will require increased expense. It is
the best means to collaborate distributedly, however.

posts.subject: #6 Client Relationship Management (CRM)

IRC has been around since the dawn of time and it is free

disadvantages:

Advantages:

might consider this a disadvantage\)

Disadvantages:

\* small expense.

Here are the specs that were previously given to Marcus for 
repository backup.

Cecelia

\-------- Original Message --------
Subject: Longer term specs for repository
Date: Fri, 12 May 2006 13:49:59 -0600
From: Cecelia Deluca <cdeluca@ucar.edu>
To: Markus Stobbs <mstobbs@ucar.edu>
CC: Gerhard Theurich <gtheurich@sgi.com>, Don Stark <stark@ucar.edu>,  Samson Cheung <cheung@math.ucdavis.edu>, Silverio Vasquez <svasquez@ucar.edu>, Aaron Andersen <aaron@ucar.edu>
References: <4462753C.4060301@ucar.edu> <8CA0AB1F-5736-4DD8-8C38-C4431FCA0833@ucar.edu> <4464BBE5.5070702@ucar.edu>

Hi Markus,

Thanks for offering us the web.ucar.edu option yesterday.
Although we ended up thinking that it's probably more
work on our end than we can handle for a short-term solution,
ESMF really should have a better repository backup in the
long term than we do.

For a longer term solution, we would need everything that's
on the original list \(with say 2X the number of people, not
all of whom might have ucar accounts, 2X the number of
machines and 10X the disk space\), PLUS we would want:
\- the ability to administer access to the repository
\(something like the SourceForge admin interface would be great\),
\- anonymous download
\- web-browsability for anyone

Thanks again,
\-- Cecelia

>> We would like to set up a CVS repository based on a source
>> distribution that's about 200MB.
>>
>> Each night, scripts from remote machines will access the computer
>> with the repository, check out the code, and run regression tests.
>>
>> These are the remote machines that we currently regression test on:
>> halem at NASA Goddard \(HP\)
>> jazz at Argonne \(linux\)
>> cg01 at MIT \(linux\)
>> columbia at NASA Ames \(Altix\)
>> phoenix at Oak Ridge \(Cray\)
>> sn702 at Cray Minnesota \(Cray\)
>> sxgate at NEC Texas \(NEC\)
>>
>> The NCAR internal machines we test on are:
>> harri, bluedawn, longs, glass, tosh, tempest
>>
>> We will also need logins on the machine for about 12
>> people, all of whom have ucar accounts.  These people will
>> need continuous access to the CVS repository.
>>
>> Thanks,
>> Cecelia

ISSUE:
Mailing lists are plagued by SPAM, and individual mail
may be too

ACTIONS:
\* Make sure everybody in the section is on board with
mailguard 

\* Test internal mailing lists \(i.e., ones that don't
have big external subscription lists\) with mailguard 
\- confirm that bad mail stays out, good mail gets in
\- make sure others in the group, esp Silverio and me,
are trained in how to look for good mail that may get
caught by mistake
\- come up with a process for checking proper function
of lists periodically

\* Clean out moderator requests for existing lists -
check there for caught good mail

\* Convert all internal lists over to mailguard:
support
training
core
\(maybe these are all done already?\)

\* The biggest external lists \(community, info\) don't
allow posts except for announcements from core and
shouldn't be put on mailguard.  Mail from
non-subscribers just gets discarded and mail from
subscribers gets held.

\* The external lists \(jst, crb, exec, adv, vendors\)
that routinely get new members and accept member posts
needs a email from us about what's happening sent to
them before they get put on mailguard - just in case
anything goes wrong or some spam starts to get through.

\* I'm not sure what policy we need for the fully
automated lists like reg and test - maybe these can
follow the same discard almost everything policy as reg
and test.

tickets.description:
ISSUE:
The ESMF Requirements doc was assembled in the first
year of the project.  Many of the items in it have been
completed, but some are not.  It is in a difficult
format to sort, search and update in real time \(latex\).
It is also integrated into the source code.

Ideally, developers, project mgmt and the CRB should
have a single source of tasks that can be sorted,
searched, and prioritized in real time.  The
Requirements doc should be culled for items that are
still not complete and these should be entered into a
SF tracker.  Initially the items may go into a separate
requirements tracker so we can get a sense of the
nature of the items and how they might integrate with
existing trackers.

The Requirements doc can then be made obsolete and
removed from both the project website and the source code.

This will solve a long-standing project issue of what
to do about the Requirements doc.  \(We tried to solve
it with the Doors package but ran into trouble with too
many unsupported platforms/browsers, and abandoned that
effort.\)

\-- Cecelia

We need to make sure the freecrm dbase is backed up
periodically and automatically.  The backup procedure
should be documented in the dev guide.

\-- Cecelia

tickets.description:
The following was submitted as Issue \#51544 with CISL Customer Support on 3/9/10:

Issue Summary:
\-------------------------
Please install Xerces C++ XML Parser in central location on Bluefire

Issue Description:
\---------------------------
In order to inter-operate with emerging systems such as Curator and ESG, ESMF is developing XML-based I/O 
capabilities, which require the use of the 3rd party Xerces C++XML Parser software.  As our user base grows and 
comes to depend on our XML I/O features, we need Xerces to be installed on supercomputer hosts in centrally 
available locations, much like netCDF is today.  So we would like to request that it be installed as such on 
Bluefire.

As a guide, you can use the installation of Xerces we currently use on Bluefire, which I installed under my home 
directory:

/blhome/eschwab/xerces/3.1.0/xlC/10.1.0.5

The path is specific for the version of Xerces, currently 3.1.0, and the version of the C++ compiler on Bluefire, 
currently 10.1.0.5.  Under this directory is the "build" directory, where I downloaded and built the Xerces source 
tarball.  There you will find my "notes" file showing the commands I used to build the library.  The commands came 
from the instructions on the Xerces website for building on AIX platforms.  Here is the website:

http://xerces.apache.org/xerces-c

On the left panel, there are links for downloading and documentation for building & installing.  Please start with 
the source tarball, currently xerces-c-3.1.0.tar.gz, and build with the current C++ compiler on Bluefire to ensure 
consistency with ESMF and other codes built on Bluefire.

Please let me know if you have any questions.

Many thanks in advance\!

Regards,
\-- Earl Schwab
ESMF Core Team
NOAA/ESRL
Boulder, CO
tickets.summary: Install Xerces C++ XML Parser on Bluefire

posts.text: Jeph Cowan of NCAR CISL support installed Xerces C++ 3.1.1 on Bluefire under /usr/local/xerces/3.1.1/xlC/10.1.0.6/ on 11/18/2010.   I reviewed it, and we switched our nightly testing to use it beginning 11/21/2010, and it has been working great since\!  See support e-mail thread under this ticket number for more details.  Corresponding CISL support ticket \#51544 closed 11/22/2010.

tickets.description:
On a regular basis \(regular being maybe loosely coupled to release schedule\) the developers should look at the compiler warnings produced during the nightly runs and decide what actions should be taken to reduce their number.

There are different flavors of compiler warnings, and obviously they also differ from compiler to compiler. Further more we may want to put stronger emphasis on warnings that come out of external demos, examples, unit test, or system test codes, than those coming out of the ESMF library. This is because the former codes are being used as examples to users.

\*gjt\*
